title: Psalms Chapter 72 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 72 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 72 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 72.

questions.question: To whom is this Psalm dedicated according to Psalms 72:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:1 explicitly states that this is a Psalm for Solomon.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:2, how shall the king judge the people?
questions.correctAnswer: With righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:2 says he shall judge thy people with righteousness.

questions.question: What will the mountains bring to the people as mentioned in Psalms 72:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Peace
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:3 states that the mountains shall bring peace to the people.

questions.question: Who will the king save according to Psalms 72:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of the needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:4 says he shall save the children of the needy.

questions.question: How long shall they fear God as mentioned in Psalms 72:5?
options: As long as the sun and moon endure
questions.correctAnswer: As long as the sun and moon endure
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:5 states they shall fear God as long as the sun and moon endure.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:6, the king shall come down like what?
questions.correctAnswer: Rain upon the mown grass
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:6 describes the king coming down like rain upon the mown grass.

questions.question: What will flourish in the king's days according to Psalms 72:7?
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:7 states that in his days the righteous shall flourish.

questions.question: From where to where shall the king have dominion according to Psalms 72:8?
options: From sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth
Only in the city of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: From sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:8 says the king shall have dominion from sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth.

questions.question: Who shall bow before the king according to Psalms 72:9?
options: They that dwell in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: They that dwell in the wilderness
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:9 says those that dwell in the wilderness shall bow before him.

questions.question: Which kings are mentioned as bringing presents in Psalms 72:10?
options: Kings of Tarshish and of the isles
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Tarshish and of the isles
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:10 mentions the kings of Tarshish and of the isles bringing presents.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 72:11, all nations shall serve the king.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:11 states that all nations shall serve him.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 72:12 says the king will ignore the needy when they cry out.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:12 clearly says he shall deliver the needy when he crieth.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 72:14 says the king will redeem souls from deceit and violence.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:14 states he shall redeem their soul from deceit and violence.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 72:15: 'And he shall live, and to him shall be given of the gold of ______:'
questions.correctAnswer: Sheba
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:15 says 'to him shall be given of the gold of Sheba.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:17, how long shall his name endure?
options: Forever and as long as the sun
questions.correctAnswer: Forever and as long as the sun
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:17 states his name shall endure forever and as long as the sun.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 72 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 72 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to show justice and mercy in their leadership role. Based on Psalms 72, what biblical principle should you share about righteous leadership?
options: Judge the people with righteousness and save the needy
Seek only personal gain and power
Ignore the poor and focus on the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: Judge the people with righteousness and save the needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:1-4 teach us that a righteous leader judges the people with fairness and saves the needy, showing mercy and justice as God's ways.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72 describe the lasting impact of godly leadership on future generations, and what practical application does this have for Christian parenting?
options: They shall fear God as long as the sun and moon endure
Children will forget the leader’s teachings quickly
Leadership has no lasting effect on families
Only immediate rewards matter in parenting
questions.correctAnswer: They shall fear God as long as the sun and moon endure
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:5 teaches that godly leadership brings reverence for God that lasts through generations, encouraging parents to instill lasting faith and obedience.

questions.question: A believer asks how to persevere through difficulties with hope. What metaphor from Psalms 72 encourages perseverance and trust in God’s provision?
options: He shall come down like rain upon the mown grass
Life is like a storm without end
questions.correctAnswer: He shall come down like rain upon the mown grass
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:6 uses the imagery of refreshing rain to show God’s provision and renewal during trials, encouraging believers to trust God’s sustaining power.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72, what role does humility and service play in leadership and kingdom work?
options: All kings shall fall down before him and serve him
Leaders must demand absolute power without accountability
Service is only for the weak
questions.correctAnswer: All kings shall fall down before him and serve him
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:11 shows that true leadership involves humility and service, where others willingly submit and serve under godly authority.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72 guide a believer’s attitude toward generosity and stewardship?
options: Kings of Tarshish and Sheba bring gifts
Wealth is a sign of God’s disapproval
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Tarshish and Sheba bring gifts
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:10 highlights the importance of generosity and giving as an expression of honor and stewardship under God’s blessing.

questions.question: In the context of forgiveness and reconciliation, what does Psalms 72 teach about the value of every person?
options: Precious shall their blood be in his sight
questions.correctAnswer: Precious shall their blood be in his sight
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:14 shows God’s deep regard and precious care for the lives of the needy, teaching believers to value and forgive others.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the needs of others and wonders how to respond. According to Psalms 72, what biblical truth encourages compassionate action?
options: He shall deliver the needy when he crieth
Ignore those in need to avoid burden
Only help those who can repay you
Compassion is a sign of weakness
questions.correctAnswer: He shall deliver the needy when he crieth
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:12 reminds us that God hears and delivers the needy, encouraging believers to respond with compassion and active help.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 72 teaches that godly rulers will bring peace and prosperity that lasts as long as the moon endures.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:7 states that in the days of a righteous ruler, peace will flourish as long as the moon endures, symbolizing lasting peace and prosperity.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72 encourage believers to pray and praise God continuously?
options: Prayer shall be made for him continually; daily shall he be praised
Prayer is unnecessary once blessings come
Praise is only for special occasions
God does not hear continuous prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer shall be made for him continually; daily shall he be praised
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:15 emphasizes ongoing prayer and praise as a response to God’s blessings, encouraging daily devotion and gratitude.

questions.question: A believer asks about the biblical foundation for contentment despite trials. What image from Psalms 72 illustrates abundant provision and contentment?
options: There shall be an handful of corn upon the mountains
Life is full of scarcity and struggle only
Blessings are only for the few
questions.correctAnswer: There shall be an handful of corn upon the mountains
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:16 uses the image of abundant harvest even in unlikely places to teach believers about God’s generous provision and contentment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72 teach about the importance of integrity and honesty in daily life and leadership?
options: Give the king thy judgments, O God, and thy righteousness
Deceit and violence are acceptable to gain power
questions.correctAnswer: Give the king thy judgments, O God, and thy righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:1 calls for God’s righteous judgments to guide the king, highlighting the importance of integrity and honesty in leadership and life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 72, the enemies of a righteous king will bow before him and be defeated.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:9 says that the enemies shall lick the dust and those in the wilderness will bow, showing God’s protection and victory for the righteous.

questions.question: A new Christian is learning about evangelism and witness. Based on Psalms 72, what encouragement can you share about the global impact of godly leadership?
options: All nations shall call him blessed
questions.correctAnswer: All nations shall call him blessed
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:17 teaches that godly leadership causes blessing to all nations, encouraging believers to share the Gospel widely.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72 illustrate the connection between prayer and praise in spiritual discipline?
options: Prayer also shall be made for him continually; and daily shall he be praised
Prayer is only occasional, and praise is rare
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer also shall be made for him continually; and daily shall he be praised
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:15 highlights the importance of continuous prayer and daily praise as spiritual disciplines that nurture faith and gratitude.

questions.question: What practical lesson about protecting and caring for the vulnerable can we learn from Psalms 72?
options: He shall spare the poor and needy, and shall save the souls of the needy
Vulnerability is to be ignored in leadership
Care for the vulnerable is optional
questions.correctAnswer: He shall spare the poor and needy, and shall save the souls of the needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:13 teaches the importance of protecting and caring for vulnerable people, guiding believers to show mercy and compassion.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 72 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 72.

questions.question: In Psalms 72:1, to whom is the Psalm attributed, and what is requested for the king?
options: Solomon; God is asked to give the king judgments and righteousness
David; God is asked to give the king strength and honor
Moses; God is asked to give the king justice and mercy
Samuel; God is asked to bless the king with wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon; God is asked to give the king judgments and righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:1 explicitly states that this is a Psalm for Solomon and requests God to give the king thy judgments and thy righteousness.

questions.question: Which literary device is primarily used in Psalms 72:3-4 to describe the peaceful reign of the king?
options: Allegory of a shepherd and sheep
Simile comparing the king to a lion
questions.correctAnswer: Personification of nature bringing peace
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:3-4 uses personification, as mountains and hills are said to bring peace by righteousness, symbolizing the harmony under the king’s rule.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:8, how extensive is the king's dominion?
options: From sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth
From the mountains to the plains, and from the north to the south
From the city gates to the farthest village
Across the deserts and the forests
questions.correctAnswer: From sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:8 explicitly describes the king’s dominion extending from sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth, indicating universal authority.

questions.question: What theme in Psalms 72:4-7 is echoed in the New Testament description of the Messiah's reign in Isaiah 11:4-6?
options: Justice for the oppressed and peace flourishing
questions.correctAnswer: Justice for the oppressed and peace flourishing
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:4-7 emphasizes justice for the needy and peace, paralleling Isaiah 11:4-6’s depiction of the Messiah judging righteously and bringing peace.

questions.question: What Hebrew word in Psalms 72:2 translated as 'righteousness' (צְדָקָה, tzedakah) implies what broader concept in biblical justice?
questions.correctAnswer: Charitable justice and social equity
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term 'tzedakah' in Psalms 72:2 denotes not only legal righteousness but also benevolence and social justice towards the poor.

questions.question: In Psalms 72:10-11, which kings are mentioned as bringing gifts and worshiping the king, indicating what about the historical-cultural context?
options: Kings of Tarshish, the isles, Sheba, and Seba; indicating international recognition
Pharaoh of Egypt and kings of Edom; indicating regional dominance
Babylonian and Assyrian kings; indicating imperial submission
Greek and Roman rulers; indicating later historical influence
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Tarshish, the isles, Sheba, and Seba; indicating international recognition
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:10-11 mentions distant kings bringing gifts, reflecting a vision of the Israelite king's universal honor in the ancient Near Eastern world.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'as long as the sun and moon endure' found in Psalms 72:5 and 7?
options: It symbolizes eternal and unchanging stability
It refers to a fixed historical period
It is a metaphor for seasonal change
It denotes the king’s mortal lifespan
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes eternal and unchanging stability
questions.explanation: The phrase underscores the perpetual nature of the king's righteous reign, using celestial bodies as symbols of permanence.

questions.question: Which New Testament figure is often typologically connected to the king described in Psalms 72, especially regarding universal dominion and justice?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The Messianic elements of universal dominion and righteous judgment in Psalms 72 are often seen as foreshadowing Jesus Christ’s reign.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 72:14 emphasizes the value of the poor's blood as precious in the sight of the king, indicating a concern for justice and human dignity.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:14 explicitly states that the poor’s blood is precious before the king, highlighting the theme of justice and care for the vulnerable.

questions.question: What agricultural imagery in Psalms 72:16 symbolizes prosperity and blessing during the king’s reign?
options: A handful of corn on the mountains and fruit shaking like Lebanon
Olive trees flourishing in the valley
questions.correctAnswer: A handful of corn on the mountains and fruit shaking like Lebanon
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:16 uses rich agricultural metaphors to describe abundance and flourishing under the king’s governance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72:17’s promise that 'His name shall endure forever' relate to the biblical theme of eternal kingship?
options: It affirms the perpetuity of the king’s legacy and divine sanction
It predicts the eventual downfall of the king
It signifies a temporary political dynasty
It refers to the king’s earthly burial site
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms the perpetuity of the king’s legacy and divine sanction
questions.explanation: The verse conveys that the king’s name and rule will be everlasting, a common biblical motif signifying divine promise and Messianic expectation.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 72:6 uses a simile to describe the king's benevolent influence?
options: He shall come down like rain upon the mown grass
He shall roar like a lion in the forest
He shall shine like the morning sun
He shall fly like an eagle over the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: He shall come down like rain upon the mown grass
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:6 employs this simile to illustrate the king’s gentle and life-giving care to his people.

questions.question: What is the significance of the closing doxology in Psalms 72:18-19 within the structure of this Psalm?
options: It praises God as the only one who performs wondrous acts, framing the entire Psalm as praise
It introduces a new theme unrelated to the Psalm’s main content
It offers a personal lament from David
It calls for a national fast and repentance
questions.correctAnswer: It praises God as the only one who performs wondrous acts, framing the entire Psalm as praise
questions.explanation: The doxology in verses 18-19 concludes the Psalm by glorifying God, reinforcing the Psalm’s purpose as a prayer for divine kingship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 72:12-13 reflect the socio-political concerns of ancient Near Eastern monarchies?
options: By emphasizing the king’s role as protector and deliverer of the needy and helpless
By focusing exclusively on military conquest
By disregarding the needs of the poor
By prioritizing temple rituals over social justice
questions.correctAnswer: By emphasizing the king’s role as protector and deliverer of the needy and helpless
questions.explanation: These verses highlight the ideal king’s responsibility to safeguard vulnerable populations, a key expectation in Near Eastern royal ideology.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 72:20, the Psalm ends with the statement that these are the prayers of Solomon.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:20 states the prayers are of David the son of Jesse, not Solomon.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 72 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 72 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:1, what two qualities does the Psalmist ask God to grant the king and his son?
questions.correctAnswer: Judgments and righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:1 explicitly requests God to give the king His judgments and righteousness, emphasizing the king’s role to govern justly. This aligns with Proverbs 20:8 and Isaiah 11:4 where righteous judgment is a mark of godly leadership.

questions.question: What is the nature of the king’s judgment over the people as described in Psalms 72:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness and judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:2 highlights that the king shall judge with righteousness and judgment, indicating fairness and justice. This reflects the biblical ideal of kingly justice as in Deuteronomy 16:18 and Romans 13:3-4.

questions.question: What imagery does Psalms 72:6 use to describe the king’s coming and blessing upon the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Rain upon the mown grass
questions.explanation: The verse metaphorically compares the king’s coming to rain watering the earth, symbolizing life-giving blessing and renewal, similar to Isaiah 55:10-11 and Ezekiel 34:26.

questions.question: What extent of dominion is attributed to the king in Psalms 72:8?
options: From sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth
From the mountains to the valleys
Over the tribes of Israel only
Over the cities of Jerusalem and Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: From sea to sea and from the river to the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 72:8 describes an expansive dominion reflecting universal reign, pointing to an eschatological king like in Isaiah 9:6-7 and Revelation 11:15 where God's kingdom is universal.

questions.question: Who are said to bring presents and gifts to the king in Psalms 72:10?
options: Kings of Tarshish and the isles, kings of Sheba and Seba
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Tarshish and the isles, kings of Sheba and Seba
questions.explanation: The verse mentions distant kings bringing gifts, indicating recognition of the king’s authority beyond Israel, similar to the visit of the Magi in Matthew 2:1-12 and the homage in Isaiah 60:6.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:12-13, what is the king’s attitude towards the needy and poor?
options: He delivers, spares, and saves them
questions.correctAnswer: He delivers, spares, and saves them
questions.explanation: These verses affirm the king’s care for the vulnerable, consistent with God's heart in passages like Psalm 146:7-9 and James 1:27, emphasizing justice and compassion.

questions.question: What does Psalms 72:14 say about the value of the needy’s blood in the sight of the king?
options: It is a cause for judgment
questions.correctAnswer: It is precious
questions.explanation: The verse declares the blood of the needy precious to the king, highlighting the sacredness of human life, paralleling Proverbs 24:11-12 and Matthew 10:29-31.

questions.question: In Psalms 72:15, what is said about the king’s life and the response of people to him?
options: He shall live and be praised daily
questions.correctAnswer: He shall live and be praised daily
questions.explanation: The verse promises longevity and continual praise for the king, reflecting messianic hope similar to Psalm 21:4 and Hebrews 7:16 concerning eternal life and praise.

questions.question: What agricultural blessings does Psalms 72:16 describe during the king’s reign?
options: Abundant corn and fruit shaking like Lebanon
questions.correctAnswer: Abundant corn and fruit shaking like Lebanon
questions.explanation: The verse uses imagery of abundant harvest to symbolize prosperity under the king’s rule, echoing blessings in Deuteronomy 28:11-12 and Joel 2:23.

questions.question: What is promised about the king’s name in Psalms 72:17?
options: His name shall endure forever and all nations shall call him blessed
questions.correctAnswer: His name shall endure forever and all nations shall call him blessed
questions.explanation: This verse speaks to the eternal and universal honor of the king’s name, a messianic prophecy affirmed in Isaiah 9:6 and Philippians 2:9-11.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of the blessing in Psalms 72:18-19?
options: Blessing and glorifying the LORD God of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Blessing and glorifying the LORD God of Israel
questions.explanation: These verses conclude by blessing God alone, emphasizing His wondrous works and glory, consistent with Deuteronomy 10:21 and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: What does Psalms 72:4 say the king will do to oppressors?
questions.correctAnswer: Break them in pieces
questions.explanation: The verse depicts the king as a defender of the oppressed by breaking the oppressor, reflecting divine justice as in Isaiah 42:3-4 and Romans 12:19.

questions.question: How long shall the people fear God according to Psalms 72:5?
options: As long as the sun and moon endure
questions.correctAnswer: As long as the sun and moon endure
questions.explanation: The verse promises enduring reverence toward God, symbolizing eternal worship as seen in Psalm 89:36-37 and Ecclesiastes 3:14.

questions.question: According to Psalms 72:9, what will the enemies of the king do?
questions.correctAnswer: Lick the dust
questions.explanation: This phrase implies complete defeat and humiliation of enemies, echoing imagery in Isaiah 49:23 and Zechariah 10:3.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the prayers of David the son of Jesse are ended' in Psalms 72:20?
options: It marks the conclusion of the psalm attributed to David
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the conclusion of the psalm attributed to David
questions.explanation: This closing verse signifies the end of the psalm and acknowledges David’s authorship, consistent with Psalm superscriptions and 2 Samuel 23:1-7 concerning David’s legacy.
